concept.label: Argentine football manager
concept.definition:
"Argentine Football Manager" (noun) 

A professional individual from Argentina who oversees and directs the operational and strategic aspects of a football team. This includes managing players and team staff, planning and conducting training sessions, devising match strategies, and making decisions on team selection. They may work at various levels of football, from local clubs to national teams. Their role is critical in the development of the team and the achievement of its sporting objectives.

data.label: Ariel Holan
data.description: Ariel Holan (born September 14, 1960 in Lomas de Zamora, Buenos Aires Province, Argentina) is a prominent Argentine soccer manager and former association football player. He has held managerial positions in several clubs including Argentinos Juniors, Arsenal de Sarandí, Defensa y Justicia, Club Atlético Banfield, Club Atlético Independiente, Santos FC, Estudiantes de La Plata, Club Deportivo Universidad Católica, Club Atlético River Plate, and Club León. His career has seen him working in Argentina's Primera División, Chile's Primera División, and Mexico's Liga MX. Holan has also worked as an expatriate football manager in Chile, Brazil, and Mexico. He is of Czech descent and stands 1.78 meters tall.
data.rationale: Ariel Holan fits the definition of an Argentine football manager as he is a professional individual from Argentina who has overseen and directed the operational and strategic aspects of various football teams. This is evidenced by his managerial positions in several clubs including Argentinos Juniors, Arsenal de Sarandí, Defensa y Justicia, Club Atlético Banfield, Club Atlético Independiente, Santos FC, Estudiantes de La Plata, Club Deportivo Universidad Católica, Club Atlético River Plate, and Club León. His role in these clubs involved managing players and team staff, planning and conducting training sessions, devising match strategies, and making decisions on team selection. His work in Argentina's Primera División, Chile's Primera División, and Mexico's Liga MX, as well as his experience as an expatriate football manager in Chile, Brazil, and Mexico, further demonstrate his professional involvement in the sport at various levels. Therefore, based on the provided definition, Ariel Holan can be classified as an Argentine football manager.

data.label: César Luis Menotti
data.description: César Luis Menotti, born on November 5, 1938 in Rosario, Santa Fe, Argentina, is a notable figure in international football. Menotti, also known as "Menotti", "C. Menotti", and "César Menotti", is an Argentine sportsman of Italian descent who has made significant contributions both as a footballer and as a manager. As a footballer, he played as a forward for clubs such as Racing Club de Avellaneda, Clube Atlético Juventus, Santos FC, Rosario Central, Boca Juniors, Argentina National Football Team, and New York Generals. As a manager, he had successful stints with FC Barcelona, Peñarol, Atlético Madrid, Newell's Old Boys, U.C. Sampdoria, Tecos F.C., Club Atlético Independiente, Club Puebla, Rosario Central, Club Atlético Huracán, Argentina National Under-20 Football Team, Boca Juniors, Argentina National Football Team, and Club Atlético River Plate. Menotti is a FIFA World Cup-winning manager, having led Argentina to victory in the 1978 World Cup. He has also managed teams in the 1982 FIFA World Cup, 1979 Copa América, and 1975 Copa América. Menotti has worked extensively as an expatriate, managing teams in Italy, Mexico, and Spain, and playing football in Brazil and the United States.
data.rationale: César Luis Menotti fits the definition of an Argentine football manager as he is a professional individual from Argentina who has overseen and directed the operational and strategic aspects of various football teams. This is evident from his managerial roles with numerous clubs and national teams, including FC Barcelona, Peñarol, Atlético Madrid, Newell's Old Boys, U.C. Sampdoria, Tecos F.C., Club Atlético Independiente, Club Puebla, Rosario Central, Club Atlético Huracán, Argentina National Under-20 Football Team, Boca Juniors, Argentina National Football Team, and Club Atlético River Plate. His responsibilities in these roles would have included managing players and team staff, planning and conducting training sessions, devising match strategies, and making decisions on team selection. His role was critical in the development of these teams and the achievement of their sporting objectives, as demonstrated by his success in leading Argentina to victory in the 1978 World Cup. Therefore, based on the provided definition and information, César Luis Menotti can be classified as an Argentine football manager.

data.label: Horacio Bongiovanni
data.description: Horacio Bongiovanni, born August 8, 1950 in Argentina, is a well-known figure in the world of football. As a midfielder, he played for Boca Juniors and achieved significant recognition as a Pan American Games medalist in football. He was particularly successful in the 1971 Pan American Games, where he not only participated as a footballer but also secured a gold medal for Argentina. Beyond his career as a player, Bongiovanni has also made a name for himself as a football manager, with notable stints at Atlético de Rafaela and Instituto Atlético Central Córdoba.
data.rationale: Horacio Bongiovanni fits the definition of an Argentine football manager as he is a professional individual from Argentina who has overseen and directed the operational and strategic aspects of a football team. This is evident from his notable stints as a football manager at Atlético de Rafaela and Instituto Atlético Central Córdoba. In these roles, it can be inferred that he managed players and team staff, planned and conducted training sessions, devised match strategies, and made decisions on team selection. His role as a manager would have been critical in the development of these teams and the achievement of their sporting objectives. Therefore, based on the provided definition and information, Horacio Bongiovanni can be classified as an Argentine football manager.

data.label: José Varacka
data.description: José Varacka (1932-2018) was an Argentine footballer and manager, known for his role as a midfielder. He was born in Buenos Aires, Argentina, and was of Slovak descent. He played for several teams, including Club Atlético River Plate, Colo-Colo, San Lorenzo de Almagro, Club Atlético Independiente, and the Argentina national football team. He also participated in the 1958 and 1966 FIFA World Cups. After his career as a footballer, Varacka became a manager, coaching various teams such as Club de Gimnasia y Esgrima La Plata, Club Atlético Atlanta, Club Atlético Huracán, Argentinos Juniors, Millonarios F.C., Boca Juniors, Atlético Junior, and Club Atlético River Plate. He also had a stint as an expatriate football manager in Colombia and an expatriate footballer in Chile.
data.rationale: José Varacka fits the definition of an Argentine football manager as he was a professional individual from Argentina who oversaw and directed the operational and strategic aspects of various football teams. This is evident from his coaching roles at several clubs, including Club de Gimnasia y Esgrima La Plata, Club Atlético Atlanta, Club Atlético Huracán, Argentinos Juniors, Millonarios F.C., Boca Juniors, Atlético Junior, and Club Atlético River Plate. His responsibilities would have included managing players and team staff, planning and conducting training sessions, devising match strategies, and making decisions on team selection. His role as a manager was critical in the development of these teams and the achievement of their sporting objectives. Furthermore, his work as a manager in Colombia and as a footballer in Chile shows that he worked at various levels of football, which is also a characteristic of an Argentine football manager as per the definition.

data.label: Mauro Navas
data.description:
Mauro Navas is a former professional footballer and current football manager hailing from Buenos Aires, Argentina. Born on October 20, 1974, he is of Spanish descent. Navas had a distinguished career as an association football defender, playing for numerous clubs including Boca Juniors, Racing Club de Avellaneda, Udinese Calcio, Club Almagro, RCD Espanyol, and Club Atlético Banfield. His career also saw him playing in the Argentine Primera División, Spain's La Liga and Segunda División, and Italy's Serie A. 

In addition to his playing career, Navas has also made a name for himself as a football manager, having managed teams including Boca Juniors, Club Atlético Fénix, Chacarita Juniors, Club Atlético Platense, and Al-Wasl F.C. data.label: Héctor Rial
data.description:
Héctor Rial (14 October 1928 – 24 February 1991) was an Argentine-Spanish footballer and manager. Born in Pergamino, Buenos Aires Province, Argentina, he was of Spanish descent. Rial spent most of his career as a forward, playing for several clubs in Uruguay, Chile, France, and Colombia. Notably, he played for Club Nacional de Football, Olympique de Marseille, Independiente Santa Fe, and Real Madrid CF. As a player for Real Madrid, he was part of the team that won the UEFA Champions League. Rial also represented Spain as an international footballer.

After his playing career, Rial transitioned to management. He managed several teams including Deportivo de La Coruña, UD Las Palmas, Elche CF, Estudiantes de La Plata, and Real Zaragoza. He also had stints as a manager in Saudi Arabia and Mexico. Rial died in Madrid in 1991. His career and contributions to football were recognised in multiple categories, including Argentine emigrants to Spain, UEFA Champions League winning players, and Argentine football managers.
data.rationale: Héctor Rial fits the definition of an Argentine football manager as he was a professional individual from Argentina who oversaw and directed the operational and strategic aspects of a football team. After his playing career, Rial transitioned to management where he managed several teams including Deportivo de La Coruña, UD Las Palmas, Elche CF, Estudiantes de La Plata, and Real Zaragoza. He also had stints as a manager in Saudi Arabia and Mexico. His role in these teams would have included managing players and team staff, planning and conducting training sessions, devising match strategies, and making decisions on team selection. His work as a manager was critical in the development of the teams he managed and the achievement of their sporting objectives. Therefore, Héctor Rial can be classified as an Argentine football manager.

data.label: Alejandro Scopelli
data.description: Alejandro Scopelli (1908–1987) was an Argentine footballer and manager of Italian descent. Born in La Plata, Argentina, Scopelli started his career as a forward for local teams Estudiantes de La Plata and Racing Club de Avellaneda before moving to Italy where he played for A.S. Roma and Red Star F.C. He also played internationally for both Argentina and Italy. His managerial career was equally expansive, with stints in Spain (Valencia CF, RCD Espanyol, RC Celta de Vigo, and Deportivo de La Coruña), Mexico (Club América), Portugal (FC Porto and C.F. Os Belenenses), and Chile (Club Universidad de Chile and Club Deportivo Palestino). Scopelli was also a player in the 1930 FIFA World Cup and a Copa América-winning player. He passed away in Mexico City in 1987.
data.rationale: Alejandro Scopelli fits the definition of an Argentine football manager as he was a professional individual from Argentina who oversaw and directed the operational and strategic aspects of various football teams. This is evident from his managerial career where he managed teams in Spain, Mexico, Portugal, and Chile. His role included managing players and team staff, planning and conducting training sessions, devising match strategies, and making decisions on team selection, as indicated by his successful stints with multiple clubs. Therefore, based on the provided definition and information about Scopelli, it can be argued that Alejandro Scopelli was an Argentine football manager.

data.label: Axel (singer)
data.description: Axel (singer), born as Axel Fernando Witteveen Pardo on January 1, 1977, is a renowned Argentine male singer-songwriter and pianist, known for his Latin pop music. He was born in Almirante Brown Partido, Buenos Aires Province, Argentina, and has Dutch descent. He began his active years in the music industry in 1999 and has since become a notable figure in the 21st-century music scene. Known for his performances at the Viña del Mar International Song Festival, he is also a recipient of the MTV Europe Music Award. Axel has composed music for shows including 'Don Juan y Su Bella Dama' and 'Mis amigos de siempre', and has been associated with other artists such as Luciano Pereyra. He has served as a judge in shows such as 'Elegidos, la música en tus manos' and 'La voz (Argentina)', and his music has been used as opening themes for shows like 'Mi corazón es tuyo' and 'Libres como el viento'.
